William would like to apply for another 25,000 PHP loan to buy more stock of school and office supplies. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result in better profits. The money he earns from his business will help him sustain his daily needs. He looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in his heart.

William hopes that his business will continue to be successful. He meets with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his life and business every week. This is where he draws strength and inspiration from the word of God he studies. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group comprises 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for office and school supplies needed in his business.

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
Marivic is 43 years old and married with two children who are in school. 

Marivic is in the agricultural business. She raises pigs in the Philippines. Marivic has requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Marivic has been raising pigs for six years now, and she has borrowed three times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

In the future, Marivic would like to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena and her retail business are doing well. She has had a convenience store for five years. She earns about PHP 300 a day. Elena is a widow. She works hard to raise her children. 

Elena wants to re-stock her sari-sari (convenience) store, but she lacks the necessary capital. For this reason, she is taking out this loan amounting to PHP 40,000 to buy grocery items such as canned goods, beverages, detergent soap and condiments to sell. She hopes that she can obtain her desired loan to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy grocery items such as canned goods, beverages, detergent soap and condiments to sell.

loans.name: Dina

texts.en:
As a married mother of two children, Dina works hard to support her family.

She has a food vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from fish vending. Dina is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF in order to buy ingredients for her food production business and for her food vending business.

Dina has been sustaining her business activities through her past three loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business.

loans.name: Ma. Cristina

texts.en:
Ma. Cristina, 39 years old, is married to a farmer and blessed with two children. She has managed a piggery business for almost ten years. In this business she earns a net income of PHP 3,000 per hog. 

She would like to avail herself of a loan amounting to PHP 5,000 to purchase hog feed for her hogs. She's hoping that her loan will be granted so that she will be able to improve further her business to gain more income.

loans.use: to purchase hog feed for her hogs.

loans.name: Donna

texts.en:
Donna is a hardworking entrepreneur who sells purified drinking water in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 14,000 through NWTF to buy more stocks of drinking water to sell to customers.

Donna successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further improve her business.

NWTF is re-listing Donna's business profile again in support of her efforts to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of drinking water to sell.

loans.name: Beverly

texts.en:
This is Beverly. She previously accessed an 20,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education and in their personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 20,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from the business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and children’s education expense. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Beverly dreams that her business will continue to grow and hopes that her children will finish their studies. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members weekly to share stories of her life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Pheach's Group

texts.en:
Pheach, a local citizen from Kampong Cham province, is 41 years old and married. She has two children. 

For her family’s sake, rice cropping on a one-hectare area and duck raising are the main income sources she has had for 10 years, earning about 40,000 KHR per day. 

Preach has never been with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner) before. She is now in a group of five to apply for a loan of 1,000,000 KHR each. As the group leader, she will use her loan portion to buy fertilizer and duck feed. She hopes both businesses will grow at a great pace so she can gain triple yield and make more profits to sustain her living.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and duck feed.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Cheung Prey district

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy ghee, sugar and other ingredients for her sweet-meat making and selling business.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
As a married mother of five children, Jocelyn works hard to support her family.

She has a butcher shop business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from buying and selling ready-to-wear clothing. 

Jocelyn is borrowing PHP 32,000 through NWTF to purchase additional stocks of meat to sell for her butcher shop business.

Jocelyn has been sustaining her business activities through her past seven loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she can send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional stocks of meat to sell.

loans.name: Perpetua

texts.en:
Perpetua is 66 years old, married, and has ten children.

She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Perpetua has been raising pigs for 13 years and also earns additional income from buying and selling dry goods.

Perpetua is borrowing PHP 11,000 through NWTF to purchase feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Neng's Group

texts.en:
Neng is 43 years old and married. She is a local resident from Kampong Cham province. To make a living, Neng works as a rice farmer and she also plants rubber trees. She is able to earn up to 24,600 KHR per day and is able to save up to 9,100 KHR per day. 

Neng is the leader of a four-woman group and this will be her first loan with the Kiva partner VisionFund. Neng is requesting a 1,000,000 KHR loan to buy more rubber tree seedlings to cultivate. Her co-borrowers are each requesting the same loan amount. In the future, Neng hopes to harvest a good rice yield to make more income to buy a plot of farmland to expand her business. She also hopes to build a new house for her family.

loans.use: to buy rubber tree seedlings to plant

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ponhea Krek district

loans.name: Cempaka Group

texts.en:
Rini is 41 years old and is a widow with two children, one of whom is in elementary school. For the past six years, she has operated a business where she sells bed linens, pillows and blouses on credit from her house. Since her husband passed away one year ago, Rini has had to work harder to provide for her family's needs. Sometimes she works as a freelance employee in a district office in her town.  Rini is a member of the community group, “Cempaka.” She is grateful to be part of this group that she feels is very hardworking and genuine. The other group members  work in various other trades including selling cooked foods and herb drinks, mostly through small kiosks

Rini is requesting a loan to purchase bed linens and Muslim fashions such as Mukena (Islam), white cloaks that cover a woman's head and body worn at prayer for Eid.

loans.use: to purchase bed linens and Muslim fashions such as white cloaks that cover a woman's head and body during prayer

loans.name: Lailanie

texts.en:
Lailanie is 25 years old and married. She works managing a store in her community. Lailanie is a happy person who is very responsible in terms of her family's needs.

Lailanie is requesting a 5,000 PHP loan to purchase boxes of candies, snack foods, canned goods, and spices for her business. In the future, her wish is to build a house for her family with the help of her husband.

loans.use: to purchase boxes of candies, snack foods, canned goods, and spices

loans.name: Lay's Group

texts.en:
Lay is 48 years old and has three children. She lives under a wooden house located in Kampong Cham province.  Lay is a local rubber grower on three hectares of land, which she has been doing for 28 years. 

Lay and her co-borrower are requesting a loan from VisionFund for 1,000,000 KHR each. As the group leader, she will use her loan to buy rubber tree seeding and potash for her farmland. She hopes to grow healthy rubber trees so that she can collect more latex to sell.

loans.use: to purchase rubber tree seeding and potash for her farmland.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ponhea Krek district

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy beads and thread for her embroidery business.

loans.name: Jose Julio

texts.es:
José, requiere de un nuevo crédito por la necesidad de invertir más en el negocio del cultivo. Este le ayudara a comprar abono, semilla y preparación para la tierra.
El préstamo anterior le ayudo a incrementar sus ingresos y aumentar el inventario. Las condiciones económicas  al igual que las circunstancias familiares han mejorado.
texts.en: Julio needs another loan which he will use to buy agricultural supplies again. This loan will help him to buy fertilizer and seeds and to prepare his land for planting. The previous loan helped him increase his profits and increase his inventory. His economic condition and the quality of life for his family have both improved.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and seeds and to prepare his land for planting.

loans.name: Lizel

texts.en:
This is Lizel who is 22 and a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Mark, an employee, and mother to her four children. Along with her husband, Lizel manages her business selling chicken and fish. She works hard to continually provide income for her family's everyday expenses. Lizel buys different kinds of fish and chicken at wholesale prices and sells them by the kilo. She buys fish at the local fish port early in the morning and many of her customers prefer her products since they are assured freshness and cleanliness. Lizel's store is located in a temporary fish market and her regular customers are her neighbors and local community members. She earns a minimum of 1,000 PHP in daily sales. 

Lizel is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan to buy more fish and chicken to sell every day. She hopes that her business will continue to grow. In the future, she dreams of having her own house and lot. Lizel meets up weekly with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business and draw strength and inspiration from studying the Word of God. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy fish and chicken to sell

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina is 40 years old and married with three children. For the past 12 years, she has run a general store in the Philippines and she also earns an income from selling food and raising pigs. Rosalina works hard to provide for her family and has borrowed and repaid 14 previous loans from NWTF. 

Rosalina is requesting a 28,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy more items to sell such as soft drinks, bread, egg, soap, noodles, and other products. In the future, she aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks, bread, egg, soap, noodles, and other products

loans.name: Georgette

texts.en:
Georgette is 53 years old, married, and has six children.  She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store and room rentals businesses in the Philippines, which she has been doing for six years.

Georgette is requesting her second loan from NWTF for 29,500 PHP, which she will use to purchase more groceries to sell.  She aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Nyabinome Tweheyo Group

texts.en:
Nyabinombe group is located in Nyabinombe Trading Centre in rural Ibanda. The group is comprised of both men and women whose major activity is small-scale farming. They fall into different categories including divorcees, widows, single mothers/fathers and married people.
 
Metusela is a father with a wife and five children and two additional dependents. Regardless of his disability, Metusela is a very economically active member of the community. Metusela is mainly a small-scale farmer who grows vegetables and supplies them in a local market. He supplements his vegetable business with a poultry farm, which he resorted to after losing his brother in 2010 so that he could look after both his and the brothers’ children and take them to school. 

He will use the loan to buy more chickens, to buy a bicycle to help him to supply his vegetables to distant customers, and pay school fees. The main challenge is chicken diseases as well as wild animals that eat his chickens after he has invested in them, which affects his working capital. Sometimes he and the family members fall sick, which reduces labor to work on his businesses. 

Despite all the challenges, Metusela is a very hardworking and determined man looking forward to changing the future of his children by giving them a good education.

loans.use: To buy chickens and a bicycle and pay school fees.
